SubTopics: Estimate the answer to addition, subtraction, and multiplication problems using whole numbers through six digits (for multiplication, no more than 2 digits × 1 digit, excluding powers of 10).
Content: Which value is closest to 79 × 4?

Key.Rationale: Rounds 79 down to 70 and 4 up to 5.

SubTopics: Compare two fractions with different numerators and different denominators (denominators limited to 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 10, 12, and 100) using the symbols >, =, or < and justify the conclusions.
Recognize and generate equivalent fractions.
Content: Asia covers about 3/10 of the land on Earth. South America covers about 12/100 of the land on Earth. Which statement correctly compares the land sizes of Asia and South America?

A.Choice: Since 12/100 is equivalent to 12/10 and 3/10 < 12/10, Asia covers less land than South America.

B.Choice: Since 3/10 is equivalent to 3/100 and 3/100 < 12/100, Asia covers less land than South  America.

C.Choice: Since 3/10 is equivalent to 30/100 and 30/100 > 12/100, Asia covers more land than South America.

D.Choice: Since 3/10 is equivalent to 93/100 and 93/100 > 12/100, Asia covers more land than South America.

Key.Rationale: Converts 3/10 to hundredths by adding 90 to both numerator and denominator.

SubTopics: Multiply a whole number by a non-unit fraction (denominators limited to 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 10, 12, and 100 and final answers do not need to be simplified or written as a mixed number).
Content: In a box of 24 chocolate pieces, 2/3 of the pieces have peanuts in them. How many of the chocolate pieces have peanuts in them?

SubTopics: Read and write whole numbers in expanded, standard, and word form through 1,000,000.
Demonstrate an understanding that in a multi-digit whole number (through 1,000,000), a digit in one place represents ten times what it represents in the place to its right.
Content: Miguel went to a baseball stadium and a football stadium.
• The baseball stadium has thirty-seven thousand, four hundred ninety-five seats.
• The football stadium has sixty-nine thousand, one hundred forty-three seats.
How many times greater is the value of the digit 3 in the number of seats at the baseball stadium than the value of the digit 3 in the number of seats at the football stadium?

Key.Rationale: States mathematical rule rather than applying it (each place to the left is 10 times greater).
Counts 3 places between the ones and tens thousands place, thus 10 × 10 × 10.

SubTopics: Round multi-digit whole numbers (through 1,000,000) to any place.
Content: Rounded to the nearest ten, 8,300 books were read by the students at Matilda’s school during a read-a-thon. Which value could be the actual total number of books read?

Key.Rationale: Rounds down to the nearest ten.

SubTopics: Multiply a whole number of up to four digits by a one-digit whole number and multiply 2 two-digit numbers.
Content: Each team in a football league has 53 players on it. There are 32 teams in the league. How many total players are in the league?

Key.Rationale: Does 32 × 53 and when multiplying 2 × 5 does not put down the 0 since there is already a (placeholder) 0 there.
Does 53 × 32 and when multiplying 3 × 3 does not put in a placeholder 0.

SubTopics: Use numbers and symbols to model the concepts of expressions and equations.
Content: Albert has been a chef for y years. Maria has been a chef for 3 years more than 2 times as many years as Albert. Which expression shows how many years Maria has been a chef?

SubTopics: Interpret a multiplication equation as a comparison. Represent verbal statements of multiplicative comparisons as multiplication equations.

Solve multi-step word problems posed with whole numbers using the four operations. Answers will be either whole numbers or have remainders that must be interpreted yielding a final answer that is a whole number. Represent these problems using equations with a symbol or letter standing for the unknown quantity.
Content: Kara, Lynn, and Molly each play on a basketball team. The points scored in their last game are listed below.
• Kara scored 3 points.
• Lynn scored 5 times as many points as Kara.
• Molly scored 7 times as many points as Kara.
How many more points did Molly score than Lynn in their last game?

SubTopics: Multiply or divide to solve word problems involving multiplicative comparison, distinguishing multiplicative comparison from additive comparison.

Solve multi-step word problems posed with whole numbers using the four operations. Answers will be either whole numbers or have remainders that must be interpreted yielding a final answer that is a whole number. Represent these problems using equations with a symbol or letter standing for the unknown quantity.
Content: Rosie, Stella, and Tiffany are all on a bowling team. In a recent game, Stella scored twice as many points as Rosie. Tiffany scored 2 more points than Rosie. Rosie scored 70 points. What is the total number of points scored by all three women?

Key.Rationale: Thinks Stella scored half as many points (35) not twice as many.
Thinks Tiffany, Stella, and Rosie all scored 72.
Thinks Tiffany and Stella both scored 140.

SubTopics: Find all factor pairs for a whole number in the interval 1 through 100. Recognize that a whole number is a multiple of each of its factors. Determine whether a given whole number in the interval 1 through 100 is a multiple of a given onedigit number. Determine whether a given whole number in the interval 1 through 100 is prime or composite.
Generate a number or shape pattern that follows a given rule. Identify apparent features of the pattern that were not explicit in the rule itself.
Content: Frank made a pattern starting with the number 7. He used the rule “add 7.” What is true about every number in Frank’s pattern?

A.Choice: Every number is a multiple of 7.

B.Choice: The last digit of every number is a 7.

Key.Rationale: Only true of the 1st term, 11th term, 21st term, 31st term, etc.

C.Choice: The first digit of every number is a 7.

Key.Rationale: Is true for some but not all.

D.Choice: The digits in every number add up to 7.

Key.Rationale: Only true for some of the terms but not all the terms.

SubTopics: Generate a number or shape pattern that follows a given rule. Identify apparent features of the pattern that were not explicit in the rule itself.
Content: Starting with an octagon, Hillary used the rule “Replace one side with two new sides” to create the pattern shown below.
problems/PA16G4M/media/11a.jpg
How many sides will the next shape in Hillary’s pattern have?

Key.Rationale: Assumes each shape has 8 sides because it starts with an octagon.
Gives the number of sides of the last shape given.
Thinks the number of sides is increasing by 2 with each iteration and not 1.

SubTopics: Determine the rule for a function given a table (limit to +, –, or × and to whole numbers).
Determine the missing elements in a function table (limit to +, –, or × and to whole numbers or money).
Content: In a video game, players can collect a special item that is worth different points based on what level of the game they are on, as shown in the table below.
problems/PA16G4M/media/12a.jpg
The pattern for the number of points for collecting the special item continues. Which statement explains how to find the correct number of points for collecting the special item while on level 5?

Key.Rationale: Returns to idea of adding 10, which only works going from level 1 to 2.

SubTopics: Draw points, lines, line segments, rays, angles (right, acute, and obtuse), and perpendicular and parallel lines. Identify these in twodimensional figures.
Content: As part of a map, Lewis drew a ray with three points labeled A, B, and C on it. The ray Lewis drew started at point A. Which could be the part of the map Lewis drew?

Key.Rationale: Confuses a ray and a line.
Confuses a ray with a line segment.
Confuses a ray with a line segment and chooses a starting point that is neither at the left-most nor right-most point.

SubTopics: Classify two-dimensional figures based on the presence or absence of parallel or perpendicular lines or the presence or absence of angles of a specified size. Recognize right triangles as a category, and identify right triangles.

Recognize a line of symmetry for a two-dimensional figure as a line across the figure such that the figure can be folded along the line into mirroring parts. Identify line-symmetric figures and draw lines of symmetry (up to two lines of symmetry).
Content: Eric is making a design for a school flag. He draws the pentagon shown below.
problems/PA16G4M/media/14a.jpg
Eric will cut the figure along a line of symmetry of the shape. What are the two shapes Eric will make?

Key.Rationale: Sees a set of parallel lines.
Draws a horizontal line through 2 vertices.
Draws a horizontal line halfway through the shape.

SubTopics: Recognize a line of symmetry for a twodimensional figure as a line across the figure such that the figure can be folded along the line into mirroring parts. Identify line-symmetric figures and draw lines of symmetry (up to two lines of symmetry).
Draw points, lines, line segments, rays, angles (right, acute, and obtuse), and perpendicular and parallel lines. Identify these in two-dimensional figures.
Content: A designer drew a line of symmetry in an angle to create two acute angles. Which figure could the designer have drawn?

Key.Rationale: Does not create a line of symmetry.
Creates two right angles, not acute angles.
Does not create a line of symmetry.

SubTopics: Solve addition and subtraction problems to find unknown angles on a diagram in real-world and mathematical problems. (Angles must be adjacent and non-overlapping.)
Content: A 90° angle is divided into three smaller angles, as shown below.
problems/PA16G4M/media/16a.jpg
The middle angle is 20°. The other two angles have the same measure. What is the measure of one of the other two angles?

Key.Rationale: 90 divided by 3 (thinks all three angles are equal).
